snippet: Carven's Guillaume Henry found inspiration in Diane Arbus photographs from the 1960s for his prefall collection.
abstract: Carven's Guillaume Henry found inspiration in Diane Arbus photographs from the 1960s for his prefall collection.
lead_paragraph: Carven's Guillaume Henry was looking at Diane Arbus photographs from the 1960s for inspiration for his prefall collection. "Ordinary people looking extraordinary," said Henry about his muse: a very specific suburban girl who rides the subway in the early morning, is moody, makes her own clothes (or wears her mother's) and wants to look pretty but can only afford synthetic shoes. Hence, the plastic tortoise kitten heels, the fabrics that make references to shag carpets and couches (her only resources) and the jackets made of a leather that's washed to look faux (she's just not that fancy). "She's sweet looking but not dull," Henry said. And she has a terrific, intuitive sense of style, one that doesn't require money. Here, because he likes "calm, strong, happy colors with metallics," is a yellow shearling jacket and skirt look paired with the coolest metallic pumps and matching camera bag. Anything but dull, indeed.
